awd_titl_txt: Frameworks: Collaborative Research: Extensible and Community-Driven Thermodynamics, Transport, and Chemical Kinetics Modeling with Cantera: Expanding to Diverse Scientific Domains
awd_abstract_narration:
Modeling and simulation play key enabling roles in aiding and accelerating discovery connecting to energy and chemical research. In applications such as energy storage and conversion, atmospheric chemistry, and catalytic chemical processing, modeling and simulation software helps facilitate technological advances. However, in recent years the available software has not kept pace with the increasing chemical complexity and interdisciplinarity of advanced technology solutions. This project addresses this gap by developing and promoting new state-of-the-art modeling capabilities for diverse scientific fields in the existing Cantera software platform. Cantera is an extensible, open-source framework that enables researchers to study basic science and support new technology development and enables teachers to demonstrate concepts and applications in their classrooms. This project extends Cantera to provide new cross-disciplinary research capabilities and provides a foundation for further community-driven improvements to the Cantera framework. Simultaneous development of the open-source platform and outreach to new user communities will facilitate both fundamental scientific insight and practical technology design and analysis, train the next generation of researchers in both software-development best practices and scientific knowledge, and generate reusable and open educational materials. In addition to work on the framework development, the project includes training of graduate students as well as education, outreach and scientific community engagement activities.


This work will develop the Cantera software platform in service of three objectives: (i) extend Cantera?s scientific capabilities to support the development of transformative technologies; (ii) expand Cantera?s user base in fields including electrochemistry, heterogeneous catalysis, and atmospheric chemistry; and (iii) broaden participation in the software?s development and management to improve Cantera?s sustainability and usability. These will be achieved by developing new scientific modeling capabilities, conducting outreach to new user communities, and improving Cantera?s architecture and software development practices. The new scientific modeling capabilities will focus on four content areas: thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, transport, and multi-phase capabilities. Outreach activities, including publications and presentations, conference workshops, and domain-specific software toolkits with examples to demonstrate Cantera operation and functionality, will engage new and existing communities. The project will establish a scientific advisory board, consisting of experts from diverse fields and backgrounds who will help guide software development and outreach. Finally, the architectural and software engineering changes in this work will improve extensibility and interoperability and implement advanced numerical algorithms to enable the application of Cantera to new types of problems. These changes will also make it easier for users to contribute to Cantera, ensure software correctness, and provide new ways of accessing Cantera?s functionality. The resulting software framework will aid in scientific discovery and development of key enabling technologies with broad societal impacts. These impacts include next-generation batteries and fuel cells for clean energy storage and conversion, catalytic and membrane reactors for electrolysis, novel fuel generation, chemical processing, environmentally conscious combustion applications, and understanding and addressing anthropogenic challenges in atmospheric chemistry.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

inst.org_lgl_bus_name: TRUSTEES OF THE COLORADO SCHOOL OF MINES

por.por_cntn:
Cantera is a community-developed, open source software tool set for calculations involving thermodynamics, chemical kinetics, and species transport.  The software is downloaded tens of thousands of times per year, and is used widely throughout combustion science, and to a lesser extent fields such as chemical engineering, electrochemistry, and planetary science.  Cantera is written in a generalized and flexible manner, so that model codes can incorporate arbitrarily complex and varying chemical models that are applicable to a wide range of problem sets.  The open-source nature of the software means that new capabilities, theories, and approaches can be added by community members so that the software remains relevant to modern scientific inquiry.

The overarching goal of this project was to enhance and extend the Cantera software suite in order to expand use to new, diverse scientific communities, grow the community of Cantera developers, and develop a sustainable funding base to support the software well into the future.

Major outcomes from this funding follow from these objectives:

  1. Expanding to new communities: electrochemistry and battery modeling.  Efforts here include (i) adding new charge-transfer reaction formulations to Cantera (Butler-Volmer and Marcus theory), (ii) development of  ‘BatCan,’ an open-source battery modeling tool (https://github.com/coresresearch/batcan) based on Cantera, (iii) demonstration of these capabilities via published papers that use BatCan to better understand lithium-sulfur and lithium-oxygen modeling, and (iv) outreach to the battery and electrochemistry modeling communities via invited talks at national (American Chemistry Society, Electrochemical Society) and international (Oxford Battery Modeling Symposium, ModVal symposium) research conferences.
  2. Expanding to new communities: we established the Cantera Scientific Advisory Board, a diverse collection of leaders from a range of scientific fields, including industry, academia, and government.  This board meets every two years and provides input to guide the future software development and governance, to help meet the needs of current and potential users, and to help ensure a sustainable future for the software.
  3. Expansion to new communities: Citations of the Cantera software package in peer reviewed literature went from 209 times per year just before the grant to more than 650 times per year by the grant’s end.  Moreover, these citations come from at least 100 unique journal titles, at least 60 of which had not previously cited Cantera.  Non-combustion-related uses increased from roughly 10% of citations to over 30% of the citing articles.
  4. Sustainable software development: the project team led a series of software workshops at a range of national and international conferences (National Combustion Meeting, International Combustion Symposium, American Chemistry Society) to help recruit new users and convert current users into software developers. These workshops 
  5. Recruiting new users and developers:
  • Cantera downloads increased, year-over-year, during the duration of the grant.  New installation methods, such as using the common ‘pip’ installation tool, made the software more accessible.
  • New developers were recruited during the grant.  Each year of the grant saw contributions from 20-25 unique contributors, with 5-10 new contributors each year.  Outreach efforts (e.g. Cantera workshops) helped recruit a new maintaining developer (i.e. one who contributes to at least 10% of the new features, each year), helping ease the individual burden on the existing maintainers.

 


Last Modified: 07/16/2024
Modified by: Steven Decaluwe
